unit_learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the auditory system, how it functions, and the importance of binaural hearing for localisation and listening in noise.
Describe and critically evaluate the properties and analysis of complex sounds, sound transmission, and sound field testing
Explain and apply the basic principles of acoustics, acoustic measures, and instrument calibration.
Describe and evaluate the common disorders of the auditory system, their underlying pathophysiology, and typical clinical outcomes.

enrolment_rules.description: (CAUD802 or CAUD8002) and (CAUD804 or CAUD8004) and (CAUD819 or CAUD8001)

assessments.description: This assessment enables the student to demonstrate their understanding of core concepts in this unit, and show their ability to integrate and apply these to clinical problems.

Thisassessment enables the student to demonstrate their understanding of a specific auditory disorder and effects of room acoustics in the application to a clinical case. The expected length is 2000 words.
This assessment enables the student to demonstrate their knowledge of the anatomy and physiology of the auditory pathway through short-answer questions.
This assessment enables the student to demonstrate their knowledge of acoustics through short-answer questions.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 1, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 1, Special circumstances

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: This unit will equip students with the theoretical concepts underpinning audiological assessment techniques and aural rehabilitation strategies. This includes an in-depth review of the anatomy and physiology of the auditory system; provide core acoustic concepts including the nature of sound and the principles of sound transmission and room acoustics and discuss how these apply to audiometric test environments and equipment calibration; and facilitate the development of problem-solving and clinical reasoning skills, particularly when audiometric information appears inconsistent.
data.title: Theoretical Bases of Audiology

description: This unit will equip students with the theoretical concepts underpinning audiological assessment techniques and aural rehabilitation strategies. This includes an in-depth review of the anatomy and physiology of the auditory system; provide core acoustic concepts including the nature of sound and the principles of sound transmission and room acoustics and discuss how these apply to audiometric test environments and equipment calibration; and facilitate the development of problem-solving and clinical reasoning skills, particularly when audiometric information appears inconsistent.
title: Theoretical Bases of Audiology
